passages.text:
On with it we go.

You find yourself flat on your back, staring up an access tube that leads to the ground above.  Muscle control hasn't yet returned to most of your body, but you manage to break the crusty seal incarcerating your eyes.  The light pours into your irises as if concentrated by a funnel.

This is the first time you've seen sunlight in nearly six hours.  You thought the light would be soothing, freeing to soak in, but it's not.  

Instead you feel like a man on a life raft dying of thirst.  Water water everywhere, but not a drop to drink.  A celibate monk at the moment of greatest temptation.  Indulgence would be fatal.

And yet you cannot help but fixate on the light above.  You lie flat on your back and stare up the well, rapt and in awe.

As you lay flat, drops of water occasionally mist your forehead.  It feels like water torture.

[[We've only been crawling through the sewer for six hours?]] 
[[p:I want to climb out.  Feel the sun and the air.]]

links.name: We've only been crawling through the sewer for six hours?
links.link: We've only been crawling through the sewer for six hours?

links.name: p:I want to climb out.  Feel the sun and the air.
links.link: p:I want to climb out.  Feel the sun and the air.

passages.name: Looking Up

passages.text:
Didn't it feel more like eight?  But yes, it's 10:00 in the morning, and you entered the tunnels outside the Cradle just after 4:00.  

If it's any consolation, that means you've been moving at a pretty steady clip.  Fifteen miles in six hours is respectable time by sewer-speed standards.

[[Continue->Looking Up]]

links.name: Continue
links.link: Looking Up

passages.name: We've only been crawling through the sewer for six hours?

passages.text:
You easily could climb this well.  Even fatigued, chimney-ing up this cylinder would require only mild sweating and grunting.

But you won't.

[[Why wouldn't I?  Why can't I just pop out the top and bask in the light?]]
[[But sunlight is the only thing I crave.  I'm climbing out of this well and basking in it for a bit.]]
[[p:It's not too late to turn back.  I can just pop out of this well and run straight out of the Cradle.]]

passages.name: p:I want to climb out.  Feel the sun and the air.

passages.text:
Alright, go for it.  No reason you can't get out of here and roll around in the fresh air for a few minutes.  You've afforded yourself that much before.  We both know you'll climb right back down though.

Go ahead.  Don't be long now.

...

See?  You don't have the nerve.  

[[Continue->p:I want to climb out.  Feel the sun and the air.]]

links.name: Continue
links.link: p:I want to climb out.  Feel the sun and the air.

passages.name: But sunlight is the only thing I crave.  I'm climbing out of this well and basking in it for a bit.

passages.text:
Well, it actually is kind of too late for that.  In the material sense, no less.  

No, really.  You've been tunneling for six hours.  You're well into the off-limits section of the Cradle.  You could probably get away with popping your head out for a few minutes, but trying to get out of here without your Ferryman guide would be suicide.  

Speaking of, shouldn't he be here by now?  You were only a few minutes ahead of him.

[[p:(Action) Shout for the Ferryman]]
[[p:(Action) Just wait and enjoy the view a bit longer]]

links.link: p:(Action) Shout for the Ferryman

links.name: p:(Action) Just wait and enjoy the view a bit longer
links.link: p:(Action) Just wait and enjoy the view a bit longer

passages.text:
Look at yourself.  You are covered in tar and stuck to the top of a terrifying but beautiful horse.  And the horse is doing its damndest to keep you down there, at the bottom of this well.  Anyone would find it difficult to climb under those circumstances.

You came here for a reason.  You might flirt with the idea of bailing, escaping your fate, but deep down we both know what track your on.

No one can help a puddle up the wall.

[[Why do I need to continue into the Cradle?  What's so important about that place?]]

links.name: Why do I need to continue into the Cradle?  What's so important about that place?
links.link: Why do I need to continue into the Cradle?  What's so important about that place?

passages.name: Why wouldn't I?  Why can't I just pop out the top and bask in the light?

passages.text:
The reverberations of your voice bouncing off the sewer walls sound unearthly and strained.  One could be forgiven for thinking that a screaming donkey in heat resided in this tunnel.

...

No response from the Ferryman.  I think its time to discontinue the experimental orchestra and get back to sunbathing.

[[p:How much longer do I have left?]]

links.name: p:How much longer do I have left?
links.link: p:How much longer do I have left?

passages.name: p:(Action) Shout for the Ferryman

passages.text:
That's a pretty enthralling circle isn't it?  Simply sublime.

But really though, how long can you stay entertained by staring at a hole in the ceiling?

[[p:How much longer do I have left?]]

links.name: p:How much longer do I have left?
links.link: p:How much longer do I have left?

passages.name: p:(Action) Just wait and enjoy the view a bit longer

passages.text:
Until the Ferryman catches up to you?  Who knows.

Or until you reach the end of this god forsaken sewer and finally find your way into the infirmary?  I don't know that either.  But probably not too long.

[[p:I just need to get in, find out what happened to Mom, and get out.  It'll be a breeze.]]

links.name: p:I just need to get in, find out what happened to Mom, and get out.  It'll be a breeze.
links.link: p:I just need to get in, find out what happened to Mom, and get out.  It'll be a breeze.

passages.text:
Yep, pretty sure the situation won't get any more complicated than that.  These tunnels will take you straight to the infirmary, right at the edge of the Cradle.  You'll pop out of an indoor manhole cover or whatever, find a nicely formatted document explaining what happend to your Mom on a nearby desk, and then escape the same way you got in.

[[You sound facetious, internal monologue.  Or whatever you are.]]
[[What if I can't find any trace of what happened to mom?]]
[[p:This will all be worth it, right?]]

links.link: p:This will all be worth it, right?

passages.text:
So you aren't too tone-deaf, it seems.  You're right, I'm being facetious.  The Cradle is never that simple.  The knotted complex of buildings inside twist and turn in every direction, full of traps and surprises.

That's why you had to hire a Ferryman as a guide.

[[Continue->p:I just need to get in, find out what happened to Mom, and get out.  It'll be a breeze.]]

links.name: Continue
links.link: p:I just need to get in, find out what happened to Mom, and get out.  It'll be a breeze.

passages.name: You sound facetious, internal monologue.  Or whatever you are.

passages.text:
If you find the closure your after, miraculously cure all your psychic ills in the process, use your newfound unhindered and undamaged brain to become rich, famous, and wildly successful, and then retire early, then sure, this excursion will be "worth it."  

But if you die here, you probably wouldn't consider it "worth it."

[[If I die I wouldn't consider it "not worth it" either, technically]]
[[0;:I'm not a sea turtle.  I'm more similar to one of those toxic octopi]]
[[1;p:Hopefully my Ferryman shows up soon, that way I can at least die closer to my goal and not in this shitty tunnel]]

links.name: If I die I wouldn't consider it "not worth it" either, technically
links.link: If I die I wouldn't consider it "not worth it" either, technically

passages.name: p:This will all be worth it, right?

passages.text:
Vacuously, that's true.  But you'd consider it a shame right now, wouldn't you?  While your still breathing?

Think about everything that would leave unresolved.  All the humiliations and all the pain that would ultimately amount to nothing if you were to die here, rendering your entire life absurd.  You don't want that do you?

You'd be comparable to one of the baby sea turtles who never makes it to the ocean.  You were born, pecked at, and now you'll die.

[[No one wants that.]] 
[[Everything is relaxed when there's no anything.]]

links.name: No one wants that.
links.link: No one wants that.

links.name: Everything is relaxed when there's no anything.
links.link: Everything is relaxed when there's no anything.

passages.name: If I die I wouldn't consider it "not worth it" either, technically

passages.text:
But plenty of people *get* that.

You think any baby sea turtle plans on being the one to get eaten by a crab?  You think any kid in Scottish folk tales plans on being one of the children dragged down by a Kelpie?

Let's make sure you aren't one of them.  Because it's a real possibility, a real fate that could befall you.

[[Continue->p:This will all be worth it, right?]]

links.name: Continue
links.link: p:This will all be worth it, right?

passages.name: No one wants that.

passages.text:
Yeah, dying after actually entering the Cradle proper would be a lot less humiliating at least.  You've gotta protect your reputation among the cabal of observers you're imagining in your head right now.

Speaking of, what's that noise?

[[Continue->Ferryman]]

links.name: Continue
links.link: Ferryman

passages.name: 1;p:Hopefully my Ferryman shows up soon, that way I can at least die closer to my goal and not in this shitty tunnel

passages.text:
So you would consider the fate of 99.9% of baby sea turtles a success?  After all, there's nothing to resolve if you've been eaten by a crab.

[[Continue->p:This will all be worth it, right?]]

links.link: p:This will all be worth it, right?

Ferryman::Is everything alright Miss?

[[Why do you think there's something wrong with me?]]
[[p:I feel fine.  What took you so long?]]

passages.name: Ferryman

Ferryman::I apologize.  I just...got concerned when I saw you lying flat on your back.

Lying in diluted sewage, no less.

[[Continue->Ferryman]]

links.name: Continue
links.link: Ferryman

passages.name: Why do you think there's something wrong with me?

passages.text:
Ferryman::Apologies for falling behind, I'm not as fit as I was when I first became a Ferryman.  I couldn't keep up with someone as athletic as yourself.  

Ferryman::...

Ferryman::Also, I knew it would be fine if you got a bit ahead.  The more labyrinthine portions of the sewers are behind us - its a straight shot from here to the infirmary, and only I have the key to the locked entrance ahead.

[[p:Alright, let's get going]]
[[p:Can I stay here just a bit longer?]]

[[p:(Action) Stand up.]]

links.name: p:(Action) Stand up.
links.link: p:(Action) Stand up.

passages.name: p:Alright, let's get going

passages.text:
Ferryman::Well... I would like to accomodate this request, but I really cannot recommend staying here any longer.  The water levels in these tunnels rise during mid-day.  And we shouldn't waste time - we don't know exactly where the documents you are after are, and we should avoid being stuck in the Cradle after sunset.

He's being polite.  Staying here any longer is an awful idea.

[[p:(Action) Stand up.]]

links.name: p:(Action) Stand up.
links.link: p:(Action) Stand up.

passages.name: p:Can I stay here just a bit longer?

passages.text:
You rise to your feet a little too quickly, leaving you slightly disoriented.  You can still make out the words of your Ferryman guide echoing down the drain.

Ferryman::The entrance to the Maternity Ward is just a bit further ahead.

[[How much further?]]
[[Will there be more sunlight up ahead?]]
[[p:Let's get going then.]]

links.link: Will there be more sunlight up ahead?

links.link: p:Let's get going then.

passages.text:
Then you're out of luck.  Organizing this infiltration took a full year.  Scrounging up enough to pay the Ferryman's broker took several months on top of that.  And that only supplemented the very large loan you took out to pay for this clandestine excursion.  

So, you better hope you find a little emotional closure somewhere in there.  You'll suffer a very poor return on investment otherwise.

[[Continue->p:I just need to get in, find out what happened to Mom, and get out.  It'll be a breeze.]]

links.name: Continue
links.link: p:I just need to get in, find out what happened to Mom, and get out.  It'll be a breeze.

passages.name: What if I can't find any trace of what happened to mom?

passages.text:
You are full of poison.  You got that much correct.  So in a way, you are pretty similar to an aquatic blue-ringed fiend.  

But you've also got a lot in common with an octopus's victim.  You're a tourist sap who ended up petrified on the beach, pumped full of tetrodotoxin, unable even to close their eyes, staring directly at the sun.

You are flat on your back, paralyzed.  You even lack the wit to shut your eyelids, and the foreign sun is turning your irises into swiss cheese.

[[Continue->p:This will all be worth it, right?]]

links.name: Continue
links.link: p:This will all be worth it, right?

passages.name: 0;:I'm not a sea turtle.  I'm more similar to one of those toxic octopi

passages.text:
Ostensibly, you came here to find out what happened to your Mom.  Everyone who comes to the Cradle is looking for closure of some form, and you're no different.  

[[Why should I care about finding my mom?  I want to run around in a grassy field and get dehydrated and then get stung by a bunch of bees, or maybe a bullet ant.]]

links.name: Why should I care about finding my mom?  I want to run around in a grassy field and get dehydrated and then get stung by a bunch of bees, or maybe a bullet ant.
links.link: Why should I care about finding my mom?  I want to run around in a grassy field and get dehydrated and then get stung by a bunch of bees, or maybe a bullet ant.

passages.name: Why do I need to continue into the Cradle?  What's so important about that place?

passages.text:
She disappeared nine years ago, when you were 13 years old.  The void she left scabbed over, got filled with scar tissue - but never really healed.  No hair follicules grow in that part of your psyche.

Your mom was research faculty at the HART generating facility in the Cradle.  She, like many others, had to drop everything and escape during the collapse.  She escaped carrying a smaller, four year old version of yourself.  

Nine years ago, she hired a Ferryman and ventured back into the Cradle, trying to salvage what she could of her research.  She didn't come back.  So you came here to retrace her steps and find out what happened.  That's why you are in a sewer and not running through a field of bullet ant infested sunflowers.

[[Continue->p:I want to climb out.  Feel the sun and the air.]]

links.name: Continue
links.link: p:I want to climb out.  Feel the sun and the air.

passages.name: Why should I care about finding my mom?  I want to run around in a grassy field and get dehydrated and then get stung by a bunch of bees, or maybe a bullet ant.

passages.text:
Ferryman::Perhaps a hundred meters, at most.  We are very close Miss.

Ferryman::In fact, that well emerges into one of the General Hospital's interior courtyards.  That's how close we are.

See?  That well was a false hope.  You made the right call.

[[C->p:(Action) Stand up.]]

links.name: C
links.link: p:(Action) Stand up.

passages.name: How much further?

passages.text:
Ferryman::Yes, actually.  The Hospital's chief architect designed the Maternity Ward to admit an abundance of natural lighting.  He believed such a design would mitigate the effects of postpartum depression.  

See?  You never needed this well.

[[C->p:(Action) Stand up.]]

links.name: C
links.link: p:(Action) Stand up.

passages.name: Will there be more sunlight up ahead?

passages.text:
The Ferryman nods his head sharply in agreement.  It's time to get a move on.

The marionette strings tugging you along grow more and more insistent.  You've been hung and drawn - now it's time to get quarted.  

Ready to get this show started?

[[p:Yes!]]
[[p:No.->p:Stop pretending that it matters, it's insulting.]]
[[p:Stop pretending that it matters, it's insulting.]]

links.link: p:Yes!

links.link: p:Stop pretending that it matters, it's insulting.

passages.name: p:Let's get going then.

passages.text:
Finally! Past grief and anger, acceptance has arrived.  We're going with the flow now.

[[C->Follow]]

links.name: C
links.link: Follow

passages.name: p:Yes!

passages.text:
Being a bad sport about it doesn't ease the pain at all.  All the anger in the world won't barter your way out of this one.

[[C->Follow]]

links.name: C
links.link: Follow

passages.name: p:Stop pretending that it matters, it's insulting.

passages.text:
The Ferryman does a quick turn and begins to slip further down the cavern.

Relunctantly, mechanically, senselessly, you begin to follow.
passages.name: Follow

passages.text:
Nap time is over.  Say goodbye to paralysis.  No more freefalls and jolts of denial.  Open your eyes to it all.  Your presence is long overdue, and the audience is getting antsy.

Not taking the bait, huh?  Seems you need a small dose of external incentivization.  Let's turn on the lights.

[[p:(Action) Raise your head and face reality.]]
[[p:(Action) Keep sulking in the moist, comfortable puddle you've carved out for yourself.]]

links.name: p:(Action) Raise your head and face reality.
links.link: p:(Action) Raise your head and face reality.

links.name: p:(Action) Keep sulking in the moist, comfortable puddle you've carved out for yourself.
links.link: p:(Action) Keep sulking in the moist, comfortable puddle you've carved out for yourself.

passages.name: Open Eye

passages.text:
That's the spirit!  Rip the bandaid off quickly!  See it all for what it really is! 

[[C->Raise head]]

links.name: C
links.link: Raise head

passages.name: p:(Action) Raise your head and face reality.

passages.text:
No, I'm very sorry, but that's no longer an option.  The haphazard equilibrium of tensile forces holding your brain machinery together has finally given way.  Tendons are snapping, bridges are resonating, and pedestrians are getting injured.

You no longer have any choice.  Open your eyes.

[[C->Raise head]]

links.name: C
links.link: Raise head

passages.name: p:(Action) Keep sulking in the moist, comfortable puddle you've carved out for yourself.

passages.text:
There you go.  No more running away.

[[I deserve this, don't I?]]
[[p:The lights, they hurt, but in a weirdly satisfying way.]]
[[p:To Hell with light, with being able to see, it stings!  Arrgh!]]

Yep.  You really earned it.

[[C->Raise head]]

links.link: Raise head

passages.name: I deserve this, don't I?

passages.text:
The lights are cleansing you.  Like a hungry dog biting off a drunkard's sugar laden, diabetic toes.  Sure, it stings, but you're better off for it.

[[p:Wait, I have toes?  That means I have fingers too, right?  Arms and legs, even?]]

links.name: p:Wait, I have toes?  That means I have fingers too, right?  Arms and legs, even?
links.link: p:Wait, I have toes?  That means I have fingers too, right?  Arms and legs, even?

passages.text:
If that's the attitude your going to adopt, go ahead and pluck out your eyes.  You've got no use for them.  Plenty of sharp wooden fragments conveniently scattered about the stage for you to choose from.  

Perhaps a member of the audience would even be so kind as to assist, for a live demonstration?

[[p:Wait!  Before I gouge my own eyes out, there's something I've got to know!  Who am I?  What kind of "thing" am I?  I want to see.]]

links.name: p:Wait!  Before I gouge my own eyes out, there's something I've got to know!  Who am I?  What kind of "thing" am I?  I want to see.
links.link: p:Wait!  Before I gouge my own eyes out, there's something I've got to know!  Who am I?  What kind of "thing" am I?  I want to see.

passages.text:
What are you?  You're a human being.  160 centimeters, 60 kilograms, 28 years old.  Female, and inexplicably muscular.  The contours of your face are beautiful, and sharp, and hard.  They cut.

[[p:No, I want to be tall and lanky and feminine, like a Borzoi wearing makeup!]]
[[p:Whatever, as long as I can beat the shit out of people.  With my face, even.]]

passages.text:
You've got it all, baby.

You're a human being, with all of the deluxe features.  160 centimeters, 60 kilograms, 28 years old.  Female, and inexplicably muscular.  The angles that frame your face are beautiful, and sharp, and hard.  They cut.

[[p:No, I want to be tall and lanky and feminine, like a Borzoi wearing makeup!]]
[[p:Whatever, as long as I can beat the shit out of people.  With my face, even.]]

links.link: p:Whatever, as long as I can beat the shit out of people.  With my face, even.

passages.name: p:Wait, I have toes?  That means I have fingers too, right?  Arms and legs, even?

passages.text:
Well, that's not who you are, and you never will be.  Feel free to torment yourself with that fixation, though.

[[C->p:Someone I dated nearly lost her finger after punching me?  What kind of fucked up life have I been living?]]

links.name: C
links.link: p:Someone I dated nearly lost her finger after punching me?  What kind of fucked up life have I been living?

passages.name: p:No, I want to be tall and lanky and feminine, like a Borzoi wearing makeup!

passages.text:
You barely remember, but your ex once punched you directly in the jaw.  Her knuckles caught on your canines, leaving an enormous gash across the span of her index.  She was too embarrassed to seek treatment, and the finger grew deeply infected.  

She was spared amputation, but the infection left her with considerable nerve damage.  She will never use the outermost two-thirds of that finger again.  You, on the other hand, were so drunk that the blow bounced right off.

So, yeah, your face has a pretty good resume for fucking stuff up.

[[p:Someone I dated nearly lost her finger after punching me?  What kind of fucked up life have I been living?]]

passages.text:
For the last four years you generated a hefty income as a horologist.  If anyone has an antique clock in need of repair, odds are you were the only one who could be trusted to fix it without destroying the innards.  This dynamic allowed you to price gouge with confidence.

You made a lot of money, and the nature of the work meant your social failings weren't too much of a burden.  It was a good gig.  So, you threw it all away to come here.

[[C->p:Someone I dated nearly lost her finger after punching me?  What kind of fucked up life have I been living?]]

links.name: C
links.link: p:Someone I dated nearly lost her finger after punching me?  What kind of fucked up life have I been living?

passages.name: Okay, but like, what do I do for work?

passages.text:
None.  Your ills are all psychic in nature.  Your brain has a few splinters embedded in it, you see.  Other than that, you are perfectly healthy.

And no, you don't have scurvy.  It is very difficult to contract scurvy.

[[C->p:Someone I dated nearly lost her finger after punching me?  What kind of fucked up life have I been living?]]

links.name: C
links.link: p:Someone I dated nearly lost her finger after punching me?  What kind of fucked up life have I been living?

passages.name: Am I suffering from any exotic medical conditions I should know about?  Do I have scurvy?

passages.text:
Hell.

Just kidding.  You're not really in Hell.  You're not really in a theater, either.  You're actually taking a nap in a wastewater tunnel.

[[p:Why the hell am I in a sewer?  Moreover, why am I taking a nap there?]]

links.name: p:Why the hell am I in a sewer?  Moreover, why am I taking a nap there?
links.link: p:Why the hell am I in a sewer?  Moreover, why am I taking a nap there?

passages.name: p:Alright, I've got a pretty good handle on my body-shape and psycho-social identity.  So, what's up with this theater?  Where am I?

passages.text:
You're in a sewer because it's the only way to reach your goal:  The Cradle.  

You're taking a nap in the sewer because you're exhausted, and you've gotten a bit ahead of your guide, the Ferryman.  He was really dragging his feet.  Might as well capitalize on the privacy.

[[C->Cradle]]

links.name: C
links.link: Cradle

passages.name: p:Why the hell am I in a sewer?  Moreover, why am I taking a nap there?

passages.text:
Yes.  You lived here right up until the collapse.  You weren't very happy here.

[[Why can't we take the train in from the surface?  That's how we got out during the mass evacuation.]]
[[p:I don't want to go back!]]

passages.name: p:The Cradle?  The underground city I grew up in?

passages.text:
The trestles for every inbound train line were imploded before the evacuation was even complete.  

None of those lines will take you to the Cradle anymore.

[[C->Evacuation lines]]

links.name: C
links.link: Evacuation lines

passages.name: Why can't we take the train in from the surface?  That's how we got out during the mass evacuation.

passages.text:
Then why did you come back?  Why leave your cushy job, just to revisit this bloated corpse of a city?

[[p:Because I have to come back.  I have to find out what happened to my Mom.]]

links.name: p:Because I have to come back.  I have to find out what happened to my Mom.
links.link: p:Because I have to come back.  I have to find out what happened to my Mom.

passages.name: p:I don't want to go back!

passages.text:
That vast, beautiful utopia that managed to flame out so dramatically within a century of its inception.  Impressive in a sense, really.

Every other surface entrance was sealed decades ago.

[[p:The Cradle?  The underground city I grew up in?]]

links.name: p:The Cradle?  The underground city I grew up in?
links.link: p:The Cradle?  The underground city I grew up in?

passages.name: Cradle

passages.text:
A few of the unidirectional outbound evacuation lines might be mostly intact.  You can't run trains inbound on those tracks, so they never bothered to collapse the trestles.

But you'd have to walk the tracks, on foot, and they are hundreds of kilometers long.

So, sewer it is then.

[[What about the routes the underground pioneers took?  Aren't those still viable?]]

links.name: What about the routes the underground pioneers took?  Aren't those still viable?
links.link: What about the routes the underground pioneers took?  Aren't those still viable?

passages.name: Evacuation lines

passages.text:
No.  Most of the underground entrances have been heavily secured.

And besides, those routes were barely "viable" to begin with.  The early underground voyage survival rates were abysmal.  

Bone Fractures.  Hypothermia.  Dehydration.  Psychosis.  Trapped by collapses.  So many ways to end up a colorfully dressed skeleton who's only remaining purpose is to serve as a waymarker for those attempting the same route.

Thankfully, the wastewater and ventillation systems were far too intricate to fully seal.  Hundreds of portals still exist only minimally secured.  

So, sewer it is then.

[[C->p:The Cradle?  The underground city I grew up in?]]

links.name: C
links.link: p:The Cradle?  The underground city I grew up in?

passages.name: What about the routes the underground pioneers took?  Aren't those still viable?

passages.text:
Every splinter ultimately must find its way out.  Return was an inevitability.  

[[So, dying of infection isn't an option?]]

Dying of infection is an option, actually.  Still on the table.

passages.text:
Mother?  You mean the woman you left behind in your escape?  Hopefully she doesn't hold that against you.

[[p:I didn't exactly have much agency during that period of my life.]]
[[p:Somehow I kind of doubt she's holding anything anymore.]]

As opposed to now?

[[C->Summary?]]

passages.name: p:I didn't exactly have much agency during that period of my life.

passages.text:
You mean other than the strings floating above you?  The knots that lead you back here?

[[C->Summary?]]

links.name: C
links.link: Summary?

passages.name: p:Somehow I kind of doubt she's holding anything anymore.

passages.text:
In any case I feel we've established the basics.  You're a healthy human being, just slightly past its prime, but with all digits included.  Your purpose right now is finding out what happened to your Mom after you left her behind fleeing a ruined city.

Any questions?
